transcript.content: Athlete and “Westside” on Xfm 104.9, sunny day, 19—uh… 2000 and… seven?
It was going so well, wasn’t it?
…once again the English language tripped you up.
The mouth with the tongue lips.
With all the… the brain… and the talk.
The brain and talk through the throat!

Rick, I think we should do some introductions ‘cause I think, it seems to me like every week we kind of… everyone knows who you are, ‘cause, you know, you’re the face of the moment. But uh they forget uh, you know, who me and the K-Man are.

… and the K-Man, who’s our producer and friend. And uh—can I just say that I really look forward to this show, right? You know, I, I get uh… “Oh great, we’re gonna do a show and we’re gonna play some tracks we like and have a laugh.” But now it’s I ca—I’m looking forward to meeting Karl.
Honestly, I come in and I see his face, and I go, “All right.” And I’m, you know, just, just great, like a, just a little friend.
D’you know what I mean? You know when a kid comes out to play with you and you go, “Aww.” And they—“Can you come out and play,” it’s like little friends, it’s like that with Karl.
Yeah. Yeah, ‘cause we don’t see him in the week, you see, we deliberately stay away from him in the week so that he’ll, you know, he’ll be fresh to us.
You start off friendly, like you did today, and as soon as Steve turns up you start getting nasty and saying things about me little bald head.

No. I said, I—look, okay, right, listen, let me explain, Karl was making the tea, and you know those bins, the sort of like round Metal Mickey-type bin you can take off a thing—oh, that would make a good little helmet, it would make him look like Metal Mickey ‘cause it’s the same shape as his head.
Right? And I put it on and…
So far so good, Rick, no problem there!
That’s just two mates having a laugh!
You putting a bin on another man’s head.
Right. So I put it on, and the swing bit, through gravity and the angle, swung and hit ‘im on the nose.
Right? He went, “Ow!” And I went, I said summat like, “It’s all right.”
Yeah, of course, ‘cause you were being amused.
Yeah, I said, “It’s all right, don’t worry.” And he went, “No, I just washed my hair.”
It’s just ‘cause, there was lots of, like, shit and coffee and, and horrible… gunk on the…
But what annoyed me was he’s hardly got any hair. So…
Let’s be honest, he looks like Moby.
…yeah, so I said… I took the bin off…
…and it, I was having a laugh, and it, I thought, “You…”
“You twat.” D’you know what I mean? I said, “Wash your hair?!” I said, “We could that now in 30 seconds!”
And he looked at me like I was in the wrong.
I know. Rick, that annoys me about him.
That does annoy me about him. But otherwise he’s sort of, he’s, like, childlike.
In so many ways. He doesn’t understand that he’s hurting your emotions and your feelings, Rick.
Nah! But, but also, right, we were playing football, I said, “Come and play football.” Right, and so we were playing football.
Was that just in the office, or…?

Yeah, just in the office, before you came, right? And uhm we were sort of kicking it back and forth, and I started kicking it a bit hard, and uh… but he was quite good, I, I said, I said, this is great, right? And uh we finished anyway ‘cause we thought we’d break summat. And uhm I went, “I bet you were quite good at football, weren’t you?” And I actually thought, I thought he looked like quite a natural, you know, I thought he’d be good, he’s from the north, I thought that he’d—that’s all he’d have.
Right? And he went, I said uh, “I suppose you’re quite good at football,” and he turned as quick as a flash and he said, “I’ve scored once.”
Right? And he said, “And that’s because I was being chased by a bee.”
No, I said, “Please! Please save it. ‘Cause I wanna tell Steve that.” Now, you can continue now.
Please tell us the rest of the story, you’ve scored a goal once…
…’cause you were being chased by a bee.
Yeah, you’ve done it now, really. I was on the uh…
There must be more to that story, K-Man.
…I was on the school team, I wasn’t that good as a kid… at football…
…mainly down to… I think it’s ‘cause of me dad, me dad wasn’t into football.
I think that’s the way it works, innit, if your dad’s into it, then you could be a footballer when you’re older.
’Cause you’re into it. And uhm… so I was in the school team because I got on with the other lads.
They let me in the team.
And uhm… yeah, I was stood there doing nothing, ‘cause I didn’t really know what to do, I didn’t—I never knew which way I was meant to be shooting.
Uh… I got all that messed up.
I just stood there, right, and uh, with me hands behind me back.
And uh something landed on me, on like this part of me thumb.
You gotta, you can’t just point, it’s radio.
The fleshy bit, the fleshy bit of the thumb, yeah.
There was a bee on me. So I start running…
…trying to get away from it, and bees… actually something interesting about bees…
…more chance of getting stung by a bee in windy weather than any other sort of weather.
And he said there was no more!
Extraordinary. I’ve already learnt… many, many things.
You’re being chased by the bee, it’s windy…
It’s on your thumb, is it still on your thumb now?
It’s sort of gripping on to me like a stag beetle.
Like a stag beetle! I love the, oh…
So I’m running, I’m running towards, like, the goal…
…“Oh God…” and the ball comes to me…
Brilliant. What happened to the bee, though, did it sting you?
I mean, ultimately, it died, sure, but I mean at that particular moment, did it sting you?
This is probably about 20 years ago so I imagine…
No no no! Once a bee stings you…
Yeah, but did it sting you?
Karl, do you mind my asking you, you say you were on the school football team, was there just 11 boys in your school?
Was that how you got onto sport?
Listen, listen, Karl. All I mean is, at what point in this story did the bee sting you, straight away? Or…
Depeche Mode, “I Feel Loved,” on Xfm 104.9. It’s about 17 minutes past one…
Well, never interrupt me when it’s going that well.
Sorry, I don’t know what I was thinking then.
That was about, that was my record, that was about four or five sentences.
True, true. I don’t know what I was thinking, I was bored.
It had semantics, syntax, there was, there was capital letters, full stops…
You didn’t even get the time right, did you?
What time was it, quick, what time was it? I interrupted, sorry, I shouldn’t have.
…one. Xfm 104.9, I’m Ricky Gervais. With me…
The K-Man, we’re all giving ourselves nicknames now.

Can I just clear something up? Just, this is, uh, you know, a very very personal thing. Uhm lots of people who listen to the show that I’ve spoken to, friends of friends and stuff, they think that I’m the guy that plays Gareth in “The Office.” Because my voice is obviously very similar.
It couldn’t be further than the truth.
It’s, it’s, I’m so, that’s so not the case. If anyone’s listening…
Could be further from the truth, it could be like a table playing it.

I don’t want to take credit for Mackenzie’s performance, that’s a guy called Mackenzie Crook, he’s a brilliant actor, everyone’s, everyone’s seen his performance, it’s not me. Admittedly, he has loosely based his accent for the character on my accent, ‘cause obviously it’s a comical accent, we all admit that.
We all agree with that. But that’s the, that’s where the similarity ends.
Mackenzie’s a good-looking fellow, in’t he?
I mean, that’s not a… that’s not…
You’re not having a dig at me, I know, ‘cause you’re saying I’m a good-looking guy as well. You know, we’re two differently… good-looking guys.

Yeah. Uh… Karl, it’s all, people are all different looks. I mean, you can say Brad Pitt’s good-looking, and you can say George Clooney’s good-looking, and they’re both great-looking blokes, they don’t look alike.
So for me to say uhm Steve and Mackenzie aren’t alike, Mackenzie’s a good-looking fella…
Exactly. You just mean Mackenzie’s a good-looking guy…
…you know, if there were a Venn diagram there, they, they wouldn’t be mutually exclusive, there’d be a crossover of good-lookingness.
I’m in that pool with Brad Pitt and George Clooney.
Well, it’s quite a big pool, Rick, and I’m in there, certainly, with them.
I’m in one of those Venn diagram circles.
You are. Yeah, you’re over this one.
I notice that’s a separate one floating off from all the others.
It’s good to be included in summink now, it’s good to be part of a gang, Karl, it’s very important.

Depeche Mode there and “I Feel Loved.” Who’d have thought Depeche Mode would’ve been that huge? I think, I think of seeing, like, little lads from Basildon with a little plinky-plonky sound, I thought, that’ll be over in—it’ll be like Visage or summat, and that’ll be it. And now they’re stadium… rock fillers…
…they’re huge. They conquered America, they went through some hard times, they came through in the end, well done.

But see, I think this is very, what you just said there is a very good example of why… they are and why certain other bands aren’t, because if you think about it… for me, you see, whenever I think of a band name, if I see a new band’s come along or whatever, I always use a very simple test. Which is, can you imagine that you’re the announcer at a huge event, maybe it’s, like, broadcasting around the world like Live Aid or summink…
…or it’s a Nelson Mandela freedom concert…
Oh, they’re all there. But you can imagine someone saying, “Ladies and gentlemen, will you please welcome to the stage… Depeche Mode!”
Exactly. But you can’t imagine someone saying, “Ladies and gentlemen, please welcome to the stage… Visage!”
“Ladies and gentlemen, will you please welcome our headline act… welcome Idlewild!”
Exactly. “Ladies and gentlemen, please welcome to the stage… Ned’s Atomic Dustbin!”
It doesn’t… do you know what I mean, you just know…
…some bands aren’t gonna make it. “Ladies and gentlemen, please welcome to the stage… Mega City Four!”
It’s just a simple test, we’d like you to do that at home…
If you’re thinking of, if you’re thinking of uh starting a band, or you’ve just named your band, you’re just beginning, just… phone in or email in, tell us what your band name is…
…and we will use that simple test.
…and we will do the test. “Ladies and gentlemen… will you please welcome to the stage…”
“Ladies and gentlemen, please welcome to the stage… Cooper Temple Clause!”
I don’t think it’s gonna happen for those lads.
It’s a simple test, anyway, but uh email…
Hundred Reasons, please welcome to the stage, Hundred Reasons?
Hundred Reasons, I think, would work quite well.
I’m just gonna give the email address, [email protected]
Ladies and gentlemen, will you please welcome to the stage… Pop Will Eat Itself!
Karl, have you got like a sound effect or something of like… to get the atmosphere if we’re going to test…
Cheering. Cheering. Well, seek it out with…

Have you got something there? Have a look. I’m just, I’m just looking in the NME uh for the kind of forthcoming gigs of the smaller-known bands, and uh it might be a useful place to uh just begin the uh… test.
Ladies and gentlemen… peoples around the world, will you please welcome to the stage… Chumbawamba!
Have you got a sound effect, have you got one?
Nice, yeah. Ladies and gentlemen, will you please welcome to the stage… the Parkinsons!
They’re playing in Leicester this week, uh… so look forward to that.
Uh let me see what else…
If anyone wants to pop down to Leicester to see the Parkinsons.
Ladies and gentlemen, please welcome to the stage… CycleFly!

Uh… there’s a, there’s a genuine one here, someone—Simon’s emailed in, he says, “Will you just test this name for us?” Okay, Karl, have you got your…  Ladies and gentlemen, will you please welcome to the stage… Coach!
It’s not too bad. It’s not too bad.
I’m worried about the sound effect, we’ll start, we’re starting to sound like Chris Moyles or summat… when you play a sound effect.
Moyles, he—well he’s a top broadcaster, everyone loves him.
Funny funny man. There’s one more coming here. I’ll just check this one.
Ladies and gentlemen, will you please welcome—this is Chris in Oxford… ladies and gentlemen, please welcome… Meanwhile, Back in Communist Russia!
I assume it’s his band, innit?
Wait, how does he listen to us in uh… Hold on, though, this is only local radio, how does he listen to us in Oxford?
Well if only there were some kind of digital format that he could listen via the web… net.
How does he listen in Oxford?
He can listen on Sky Digital…
Okay, what would that Web address be?
…and uh… you get, you get Xfm ten seconds behind what actually happened.
Just, just out of interest… what’s the point of saying that they, if they can’t sort of get us in London, to listen… to that, because…
…they won’t be… they’re either, they’re already, they’re either in London.. so they won’t go through this nonsense… or they’re in Leicester… and they can’t hear us saying Sky Digital, and…
Yeah, we haven’t thought that through at all.
Because you might work in London for a bit, and then…
Go back and spread the word.
Go back and spread the word like disciples.
Soon Xfm is the most listened-to radio station in Britain.
What we need is uh people on Radio 2 to give it a plug everyday.
Yeah. Yeah. Any of the big rivals. Virgin. We’ve often plugged Virgin, it’s a good station.
It’s a great station. Really good station.
(in smooth DJ voice) You’re listening to Magic 105.4.
Are you getting… you’re getting quite a lot of voice-over work now, aren’t you?
Well you know, I… you know, I’m all right now, I’ve got a bit of money.
Classic 60’s bands, I’ve just… Ladies and gentlemen, will you please welcome to the stage… the Scaffold!
Do you remember the Scaffold, Karl?
You’ve picked a—the lead singer looks a bit like him. But you know whose brother that is in the Scaffold, don’t ya? Mike McGear? Do you know whose brother that is?
Do you remember the Scaffold, they did uh…
(singing) “We’ll drink a drink a drink to Lily the pink the pink the pink…”
Yeah. (sings) “Thank you very much for the Aintree Iron.” Do you know whose brother that is?
No, Mike McGear, innit, the sort of—one of the main men in it.
He’s one of the songwriters in uh…
Yeah. That’s Paul McCartney’s brother. Think, think… think of that when they go around for Christmas.
So I think “Lily the Pink” was what, about 1970?
Yeah yeah yeah, it was number one, wasn’t it, Christmas number one.
Yeah, big number one, yeah, I mean I don’t know if it was Christmas number one. “Two Little Boys” was 1969, last hit of the ‘60s.
Yeah, it definitely was number one. The Scaffold was—
Yeah, but I don’t know if it was—
It was, it was, it was, ‘cause I remember I did read it in the Sunday Times.

Yeah. So they go home for Christmas… Mrs. McCartney goes, “All right, boys. How are you, Paul, how are you doin’?” “I’m startin’ a new band called Wings.” “Oh yeah, yeah.” “This is Linda.” “All right, lovely, sit down. Mike, what are you doin’?” “Just had a number one.” “Brilliant, round of applause.” “How many number ones do you have, Paul?” “Uh… 19.” “Still. We know what we like, don’t we?”
(singing) “We’ll drink a drink a drink to Lily the pink the pink the pink…”
Paul goes, “Well, if you wanna… (sings) ‘The long and winding road…’”
“Boring! (sings) 'We’ll drink a drink a drink to Lily the pink…'”
“Linda, do you wanna be in uh the Scaffold, we’re probably gonna go on tour and stuff, I know you’ll love it.” “Well, I’d quite like it, yeah.”
(sings) “We’ll drink a drink a drink to Lily the pink the pink…”
“You’re not gonna be in Wings if you’re gonna play with him.”
“Well, I gotta, you know, make a tricky decision, I mean that’s a great song, everyone’s loving it, it’s Christmas number one.”
“What are you doing, what are you doing eating his bacon?”
“Yeah, but I love the music, it’s, I mean, he’s a great guy.”
“Well, stop it! What are you doing?”
“Well I just, you know, I love the… (sings) ‘We’ll drink a drink a drink to Lily the pink the pink the pink…’”
(sings) “’Yesterday… all my troubles seem so—‘“ (unable to reach note) “Oh shut up.”
Oh, imagine that, ‘cause imagine the idea of going, “Well you’ve had 19 number ones. I mean, you know…”
Yeah, “If things stay like this for the Scaffold…”
“If things carry on going like they’re going now…”
“…the Scaffold could…” Ladies and gentlemen, will you please welcome…
Please welcome to the stage… Beck!
Dandy Warhols. Ladies and gentlemen, please welcome… the Dandy Warhols.
There you are. It’s not, it’s never gonna happen for them.
That sounds like… Levellers crossed with… Wonder Stuff.
I mean it’s fine, it’s chirpy, it’s…
It’s a nice enough song but it’s, you know, it’s not…
It’s that thing of it’s just not essential…
…you don’t really need it in your life. If it never occurred, you wouldn’t mind.
You know what Karl just said?

He looked out the window, and he looked at me—and he was looking at me, and I looked over at him and he said, “See? Now’s the t—that’s, that… would be good to die now.” I went, “What?” He went, “That weather, that would be good to die.” And I said, “Of what?” He went, “Old age.”
He’s on a different plane to us.
No, don’t say it like that. The other week, I came in when it was really miserable, and I said to you, “God, can you imagine dying today?”
Whereas today you feel it would be a much better day to die ‘cause it’s bright.
Get the curtains open, sun’s shining, it’s like…
I mean, you’d still be a bit angsty about the dying thing, wouldn’t you, I mean I don’t suppose that would be alleviated.
Hopefully we’ll still be broadcasting, you know, when one of us reaches that happy moment and we can uh, we can check.
Quite a lot of emails, Rick, coming in about uh band names. I think a lot of people have gotten it wrong for a simple reason. They think it’s funny to have an ironic band name.
They think it’s a bit comical, and I just don’t think there’s any great bands that have had a comical name, that have made it into stadium-filling…
What was that, what was that band, “Where’s Me Jumper?” What were they called?
I don’t know what they were called. I mean the obvious example of one that, that was never gonna make it, internationally…
Ladies and gentlemen, please welcome to the stage… Carter the Unstoppable Sex Machine!

These are some of the ones we’ve had emailed in, these are bands obviously that haven’t made it, made it so far and I don’t think they will. Ladies and gentlemen please welcome to the stage… the Lazy Birds! Tsk. Nope.
Ladies and gentlemen please welcome to the stage… the Paper Clips!
That’s not a real band, is it?!
I love the idea—but no band name is weirder than the others, and also you grow into it. I mean, the S—“The Stones” and “The Beatles” are iconic because they are iconic bands.
What, you think you’ll grow into—Ladies and gentlemen please welcome… Shuttle Rock!
Ladies and gentlemen please welcome… Treehouse Casino!
But my point is people say there’s no logic to band names, but if you think of a band name like “The Smiths”…
It sums up everything that band is about, you know, the kind of, they’re capturing that mediocre world of grim up-northness, you know.
These are, these are incredible na—band names. So there is some logic to it.
Madness, Madness sounds rubbish but they’re good, aren’t they?
Yeah, but again, they’re never gonna be… they’re never gonna be world-beaters…
But they were a comical band, essentially.
They were a knees-up party band and Madness is fine for that.
But they had some great songs as well, and, it, but, then it, then it sort of turned it all ‘cause then—
I mean Rick, I don’t know how many members…
“Not Home Today” is a great song, and a serious song.
This is from an email, I don’t know how many members of the band there are in Chimney Factory…
…but which---if there’s five people, who decided, had they all agreed, “Yeah, that’s a great—that’s the best name we can come up with.”
Do you know who I reckon decided? Dell.

He, he started the band and they rehearsed ‘round his house, so Dell went, “Look, it’s called Chimney Factory, it’s my…” “All right, Dell, but it’s not—I’ve got some other—" “No. It’s called Chimney Factory.”
“I’ve got—I am the van and the amps.”
“Is Paper Clips gone?” “There’s a band in Leicester called Paper Clips.”
“We can’t… you know, we’ll just argue over that, forever.”
And it’s just—all I’m saying is, think before you name your band, all right? ‘Cause it’s never gonna happen if you’ve got a comical band name.
There was a feminist band called Clitoris Allsorts.
Yeah, but you laugh, and then you just think, ugh…
…you know, I’’m never gonna have that on my T-shirt.
It’s that time of the day now, talking of that.

Now… Steve, I mean, I will play great old tunes ‘til the cows come home, we’ve got, we’ve gotta give ‘em a little bit of Dandy Warhols and Air and Athlete, I know that and they’re great, they’re good, right? But… uhm I wanted to play a Cat Stevens song but I thought I better not ‘cause I’ve, you know, played that a little bit. And we’ve quite liked resurrecting old reputations, don’t we, people like Elton John, who uh had bad phases, or David Bowie and uh…
People whose names now are largely laughed at in…
Or people that people might not have considered. I thought Cat Stevens, oh no… Rod Stewart, I thought…
Oh see, Rod Stewart, many people now are thinking of the leopard hot pants and the ludicrous…

Yeah, “Da Ya Think I’m Sexy?” and all those sort of awful stadium sort of disco things but he wrote beautiful tracks, from “Maggie May” through… and I thought, hold on, two birds with one stone. What about a Rod Stewart song… written by Cat Stevens?
Wow. Is there such a thing?
On this album as well… is “The Killing of George”… “—Georgie, Part I and II,” remember? About the gay bloke who… (sings) “Georgie boy was gay I guess.” His favorite song.

And uh I was going, “Oh yeah, I remember that, yeah.” I said but uh, and I said uh… (sings) “They did not intend to take his life, he just pushed—“ When he gets mugged and killed, do you know what he said?
I was sitting outside, I was singing, trying to… he went, “Well, I sa—as I said, they go out too late.”

Yeah, he meant gay people go out too late. He went, “No, they do.” “What do you mean?” He said, “They’re always out, they go out when people are coming home.” He said, “If he’d have been in bed by ten he’d still be alive today.”
And he went, “There’s one that works here and he’s shattered every Monday.”
Oh, if you’re gay and you’re listening, just… be in bed earlier, go out when sensible people go out.
You’re right, we’re not on the continent, Karl, is your point.
If you, if you’re gay and you’re not in bed by ten, go home.
“First Cut Is the Deepest,” Rod Stewart.
Rod Stewart – The First Cut Is the Deepest
Air. "Don’t Be Light." Xfm 104.9. Five to two…
And, the K-Man. KP, Karl Pilkington, the K-Man.
Yeah. See that in Heat this week?
About the campaign to stop Karl going back to Manchester—you know ‘cause he’s a miserable sort of Northerner, goes “London’s crap and I wanna go back up north.”
And “I, I only need forty quid a week to live up there like a king. And all that sort.”
Rubbish. Right? Well ah uhm uh… Boyd from Heat, uhm probably met him at the uhm, that awards ceremony.
And uh he was saying about “Oh yeah he’s brilliant” he enjoys Karl—he’s getting a lot of—people like Karl.
A lot of people love him. They love him.

And I was going “Yeah but he’s thinking of leaving,” and he was going “Aww, I’ll s—start a campaign” and he did, he p—put it in there. So the campaign—so write in if you like Karl. If, if, if you think he’s really annoying, then we’ll stop talking to him.
But I mean I like him.
Have you ever read the uh White Man, the White Van Man column in the Sun, Karl?

Are you familiar with it? This is where everyday in the Sun they interview a guy who drives a, a van, a white van just, you know, in order to get the kind of voice of the man on the street in the paper. And he has to answer, or just give his opinions really on uh events that have made the news each week. Just thought we could maybe throw some of these at you, Karl.
‘Cause we know—just to see what your views are.
So uhm just the first thing that comes into your mind, the sort of—your initial reaction, to these uh…
Just talk about these, you don’t need to know about them, it’s just your philosophy on it, so, you know.
I have had a few days off this week, remember, so I don’t know what’s going on in the world.
Yeah, you—I mean, you stayed in London though, didn’t you? You didn’t travel.
You didn’t bury yourself, did you?
I normally see the news but I didn’t… this week.
Okay. Uhm, so what are your view—what was your view on Will Young beating Gareth Gates in the final of Pop Idol?
Don’t like him. You know what I was thinking about when I was watching it all the way through?
How he looks like he’s got a wire coat hanger in his gob.
Again it’s radio, Karl. It’s a great face…
Yeah, uhm, you know, but, you know, a radio…
And is that—that’s a problem for you, is it?
And just the way he’s from a really rich family. I opened up the paper on a Monday or something and it had like how he went to a posh school and he’s got loads of money already.
Uhm… there’ve been huge rises in street crime especially muggings and carjackings, what’s your view there?
More youth clubs are needed, aren’t they?
No, I like that because it’s so 1950’s.
It’s sort of like he wants a bobby on the beat that’ll clip you ‘round the ear.
So once they’ve come out of national service…
Yeah. No, I love that and if, and if you find someone smoking a Woodbine you make ‘em smoke fifty.
Oh, this is great. That is great.
Did you, did you used to go to uh youth clubs?
And they, they kept you out of trouble?
Uh, used to get into a fight afterwards when we came out.
Sure, but for the sort of hour and a half you were there…
You had a bit of pool and some boxing and… a bit of pop.
So more, more youth clubs, that’s good.
I love him. I love him. If you’re at home ju—just make notes ‘cause this is brilliant stuff, honestly, you won’t hear more honest, from-the-heart—
—stuff than this. This is great. Go on.
This is not pre-planned, this is really your direct responses now that you’re giving…
Oh I promise you, Karl did not know what we were gonna d—he never knows what we’re gonna do and… he always answers honestly, that is the beauty of Karl.
What is your view, Karl, on New York’s former mayor becoming Sir Rudy Giuliani? Sir Rudy Giuliani?
He appears to be pleased with it.
Let it go ahead! Oh it’s genius.
“Is he happy with it?” He’s like your nan!
Yeah, yeah. What do you make of Michael Greco’s character Beppe being axed from “Eastenders”?
The whole soap thing, whats-it’s back in “Coronation Street,” isn’t she? Uh, what’s her name?
Bet Lynch. She thought she’d go off and be a bigger star…
All went wrong, and now she’s coming back.
Sure. Sure. Well the final one—
What’s the van reply, what’s the guy in the…
White Van Man says uh, “Obviously they feel the character’s run its course…”
“But I think he’s a pretty good actor and I can’t understand why.” I mean, obviously there’s a White Van Man there who’s also got an opinion on script development.
The through line, yeah, the narrative through line of the soap opera.
The twelve-week narrative, the arc really shows itself up.
Two last ones I want your opinion on here. What do you make of a cat cloned in a secret 2.5 million research project?
If they can clone cats. Yeah.
Have they had to hurt it?
Have they had to sort of hurt it to do that?
Have they had to hurt it?
Or is it just scraping its tongue for some stuff?

That cat, what if that cat turned out to be a world dictator?
Exactly. What do you reckon of cloning generally, Karl, you’re concerned about it?
What do you think of cloning for organs, you know, they grow ‘em for the, you know…
Do you know what cloning means?
Yeah, it’s when you like make something else that’s the same, innit?
Yeah, I mean it’s not gonna do any harm.
He’s great. Put him on the World Council.

What do I make of it?
Yeah. Is that a problem for you, do you think that’s unprofessional?
Was it the lunch break or…
I think it was lunch break.
It was their own time, fair enough. It only takes 45 seconds to go from the bottom to the top, is that a problem?
They moved quickly, they acted, you know, on instinct. You think fair enough, if that’s their natural instincts, and they’re both consenting you think, fine.
We’ll have more of Karl’s world-weary opinions next time on the show. Listen, I want to play A Track That I Love.
